title: 111_s3238
content: The Act may be cited as the "Fallen Heroes of 9/11 Act". Congressional findings are also included in the Act. Congress finds that the tragic deaths on September 11, 2001, have forever changed the nation. The responders who perished at the World Trade Center showed heroic action. The tragic events of September 11, 2001 saw heroic actions from various individuals, including officers, emergency rescue workers, and government employees responding to the Pentagon attack, as well as the passengers and crew of United Airlines Flight 93 who prevented further harm. The heroic actions of individuals aboard United Airlines Flight 93 prevented the aircraft from being used as a weapon, recognizing their sacrifice with an appropriate medal is fitting in light of the unprecedented attacks on the United States on September 11, 2001. SEC. 3. Fallen heroes of 9/11 congressional medals. The President is authorized to award a medal known as the "Fallen Heroes of 9/11 Congressional Medal" to individuals and organizations in recognition of their sacrifices and to honor those who died on and after September 11, 2001. This includes personal representatives or next of kin, the Flight 93 National Memorial Project, the National September 11 Memorial and Museum, and the Pentagon Memorial Project. The Secretary of the Treasury shall strike 3 designs of medals to honor those who lost their lives in the 9/11 attacks at the World Trade Center, the Flight 93 National Memorial Project, the National September 11 Memorial and Museum in New York, and the Pentagon Memorial Project at the Pentagon. The Secretary of the Treasury will create medals to honor those who died in the 9/11 attacks at the World Trade Center, Pentagon, and Flight 93 in Pennsylvania. The Secretary of the Treasury will create silver and gold medals to honor individuals who died in the 9/11 attacks, including passengers and crew of American Airlines Flight 77. Before finalizing the design, the Secretary will consult with the Secretary of Defense and other relevant parties. Eligibility to receive the medal extends to individuals who died on or after the attacks. Individuals who died on or after September 11, 2001, as a direct result of the acts of terrorism within the United States on that date, shall be eligible for a medal authorized by the Secretary, in consultation with other relevant officials. Individuals who died on or after September 11, 2001, as a direct result of the acts of terrorism within the United States on that date, shall be eligible for a medal authorized by the Secretary, in consultation with other relevant officials. SEC. 4. DUPLICATE MEDALS. The Secretary will create duplicate bronze medals for officers, emergency workers, and other employees of government agencies who were assigned to duty stations on September 11, 2001, for display in their respective workplaces. Officers, emergency workers, and government employees who responded to the 9/11 attacks and died as a result, including those missing and presumed dead. SEC. 5. ESTABLISHMENT OF LISTS OF RECIPIENTS. Before the end of the 120-day period after the enactment of this Act, the Secretary will establish lists of individuals eligible for a medal under section 3(c)(1) and eligible recipients of a duplicate medal under section 4. The Secretary will establish lists of eligible recipients for a medal and consult various organizations for determinations. The lists and inclusions/exclusions are final. The Secretary will establish lists of eligible recipients for a medal, and decisions on inclusion/exclusion are final. If someone becomes eligible for a medal or duplicate, their name will be promptly added to the appropriate list. The Secretary may sell duplicate bronze medals to the public to cover costs. The medals struck under this Act are considered national medals.
